IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: Collection and Preservation of Art for Public Exhibition.
IRS990.MissionDescription: THE MISSION OF THE PORTLAND ART MUSEUM IS TO SERVE THE PUBLIC BY PROVIDING ACCESS TO ART OF ENDURING QUALITY, BY EDUCATING A DIVERSE AUDIENCE ABOUT ART, AND BY COLLECTING AND PRESERVING A WIDE RANGE OF ART FOR THE ENRICHMENT OF PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS.
IRS990.Description: The Museum devotes 90 percent of its galleries to its permanent collections which consists of more than 50,000 objects. It also maintains an ambitious exhibition program, presenting approximately 20 major and minor exhibitions each year. Highlights for fiscal year 2010 were: China Design Now, Disquieted, Raphael: The Woman with the Veil, Marking Portland: The Art of the Tattoo. See Schedule O for continuation.During the year, more than 300,000 people (including 50,000 children) used the Museum and its programs. The ongoing work of the museum includes the preservation, cataloguing, and research into the works of art in the permanent collection.

Activity2.Description: The Museum's Northwest Film Center conducts an active film and video exhibition program, operates the oldest and most comprehensive film school in Oregon and the Northwest, and has one of the premiere youth media arts residency programs in the nation. During the year, over 10,000 students were impacted by our programs, either by direct instruction or through public programs.

Activity3.Description: Museum Education Programs aim to broaden and deepen access to art to diverse audiences, and to facilitate visitors' learning about art both on and offsite. More than 23,500 students and teachers toured through exhibitions and the collections during the 2009-2010 school year. The Museum also made available an iPod-based multimedia tour of the permanent collection and select exhibitions free to all visitors, held 29 public lectures and symposia, presented free family days for over 8,000 visitors cumulatively, and continued to offer art-making with local artists to children at the museum on Sundays. Outside our walls we visited more than 4,100 students in their own classroom as part of our "museum suitcase" outreach program.

IRS990ScheduleA.GeneralExplanation: Schedule A, Part II, Line 10, Explanation of Other Income: Other Income

OtherSecurities.Description: Interests in assets held at Oregon Community Foundation

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Museum's collections comprise more than 50,000 objects and works of art, including works of European painting and sculpture, American painting and sculpture, silver, Asian art, Native American art, Pre-Columbian art, Cameroon and other African art, contemporary art, sculpture, prints and drawings, and photography. The collections are maintained for public exhibition, education, and research in furtherance of public service, rather than for financial gain. The Museum's collections, acquired through purchase and donation, are not recognized as assets in the accompanying financial statements. Purchases of collection items are recorded in the year in which the items were acquired as decreases in unrestricted or temporarily restricted net assets, depending on the source of the assets used to purchase the items and whether those assets were restricted by donors. Contributed collection items are not reflected in the financial statements. Pursuant to Museum policy, proceeds from the sale of art and related insurance settlements are recorded as temporarily restricted net assets for the acquisition of works of art.

The permanent collection is at the core of the Museum's mission to collect and preserve a variety of art for the enrichment of present and future generations. Displayed in 112,000 square feet of galleries, the museum's collection of more than 50,000 objects reflects the history of art from ancient times to today. The collection is distinguished for its holdings of arts of the native peoples of North America, english silver, and the graphic arts. An active collecting institution, the museum devotes 90 percent of its galleries to the permanent collection.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Museum's endowments are used to fund certain curatorial and management positions, to purchase, preserve, and display specific types of art, to support education and Northwest Film Center activities and for the unrestricted support of overall Museum operations.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Oregon Media Art Fellowships are awarded for past creative work, therefore there is no monitoring on how the funds are spent by the various recipients.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: The Arlington Business Club is used for entertaining and business discussions in Portland.
The employment contracts approved by the Board of Trustees includes Arlington Club benefit information.

Form990ScheduleMPartII.Identifier: Method for Determining Number of Contributors:
Form990ScheduleMPartII.Explanation: Numbers listed in column B represent the number of contributions received.
Consistent with its accounting policy related to contributed art to its art collection, as described in schedule D, contribution of collection items are not reported as revenues.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 2
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Helena Lankton and Jim Rudd - business relationship James Winkler and Harold Schnitzer - business relationship Peter and Julie Stott - family relationship Harold and Arlene Schnitzer - family relationship William and Helen Jo Whitsell - family relationship Melvin Mark and Linda Andrews - family relationship

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Form 990 is prepared by an independent CPA firm based on information provided by Museum staff. The return is then reviewed by senior management and reviewed and approved by the Finance Committee of the Board. A copy of the return is then given to all board members before being submitted.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Trustees are required to sign the conflict of interest policy annually as part of the Board orientation process. The governance committee of the board of directors is in charge of monitoring all potential conflict of interests. If a conflict of interest arises, the interest of the trustee is put on record, and the trustee will be excused during the discussion of the matter, as well as the voting process.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The compensation of the Executive Director was determined at the time of initial hiring by the hiring committee, based on information provided by an outside HR consulting firm, and reviewed and approved by the board of directors. Subsequent year adjustments are based on comparability data, and are approved by the board of directors.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The audited financial statements are available as a downloadable pdf file on the Museum's website or in hard copy upon request. No other documents are made available to the public.
